LJava
Class Relation

java.lang.Object
  LJava.Relation
All Implemented Interfaces:
QueryParameter
public class Relation
extends java.lang.Object
implements QueryParameter

This class carries all properties and methods for a relation in the engine's database. Relations are the base of the logical work behind the engine. Queries, Functions, conducts, exists, all those are working with relations to return values as answers to a research or a search. Besides Variables, all other structures in LJava are relations. Relation is immutable once created. You can change the content of an Object which appears in the arguments of a relation but you cannot change the objects a relation is pointing to. A care should be taken with placing mutable objects as a relation's arguments (with the exception of Variable).

Author:
Tzali Maimon

Constructor Detail

Relation

public Relation(java.lang.String n,
                java.lang.Object... params)
Constructs a new in-order relation with a name and parameters. A name is not one of the relation parameters. NOTE: using "#" at the beginning of the name for a relation will cause the logical engine to think of this relation as a nameless relation, thus allowing it to be compared with other nameless relations regardless of their name property.

Parameters:
n - A name.
params - Parameters of the relation.

Relation

public Relation(int i,
                java.lang.String n,
                java.lang.Object... args)
Constructs a new relation with a name and parameters. A name is not one of the relation parameters. As first parameter, placing INORDER will create an in-order relation and placing INSET will create a set relation. NOTE: using "#" at the beginning of the name for a relation will cause the logical engine to think of this relation as a nameless relation, thus allowing it to be compared with the database according to its arguments alone.

Parameters:
i - The type of the relation.
n - A name
args - Parameters.
Method Detail

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object

name

public java.lang.String name()
Returns the name of the relation.

Returns:
A string.

args

public java.lang.Object[] args()
Returns an array of objects which is the a clone of the array of arguments of the relation. NOTE: this is a shallow copy and thus changing an object in the returning array will change the object inside the relation. Any use of mutable objects as a relation parameters should be considered carefully.

Returns:
An array of Objects.

type

public int type()
Return the type of this relation: 0 for in-order relation, 1 for a set relation.

Returns:
An integer.

True if equals.

relationStructureCompare

public boolean relationStructureCompare(Relation r)
Compare the structure of this relation to a given relation. Structure compare doesn't compare values in the arguments of the relations but only checks that the relation has the same general structure (same amount of arguments, same name).

Parameters:
r - A given relation
Returns:
A boolean expression, return true if both relations has the same structure.

replaceVariables

public Relation replaceVariables(java.lang.String s)
Returns a new relation which is exactly as this Relation but replacing all the variables which aren't instantiated. The name of the new relation should be given. The new relation is of the same type as the given one. Note: each variable is changed into a different value independent to place in the relation's arguments. That is to say that relation r1(x,x,1) will turn into (y,y,1).

Parameters:
s - A name for the new relation.
Returns:
a copy of the given relation with different variables as described.
